awd_titl_txt: Quantifying dense gas dispersion in urban areas
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal: 1703548
PI: Nigel Kaye

Urban canopies can reduce pollution dispersion, leading to increased local concentrations of pollutants. The physics of dense gas dispersion in urban areas is poorly understood because of the health risks, cost, and measurement resolution limitations of large-scale field studies. One goal of this research is to develop a new laboratory method for safely studying dense gas dispersion in urban areas at a spatial resolution not previously achieved, and use this method to undertake high resolution, statistically rigorous validation of computational models.

The research will study the influence of topography-generated turbulence on building-scale mixing of dense gasses trapped in urban canopies. The experimental technique will use simultaneous particle tracking and light-induced fluorescence measurements of salt water being dispersed by a freshwater flow. The simultaneous measurements of the time-varying velocity and density fields will enable the calculation of the turbulent pollutant flux along with all other mean and turbulent properties of the flow. Experimental and published data will be used in a detailed statistical validation study of computational fluid dynamics sub-grid-scale models to assess their ability to model dense gas dispersion. The technique has significant advantages over full-scale testing as it is cheaper, offers greater parameter and boundary condition control and hence greater repeatability, has significantly improved measurement spatial resolution, and does not require releasing dangerous chemicals into the environment.  In terms of the broader impacts, the experimental technique developed will transform the study of dense gas dispersion in urban areas through improved spatial and temporal resolution. The measurements will enable the quantification of local mixing processes that are particularly important in geometrically complex regions like urban canopies.  The primary societal benefit will be as a tool for responding to emergency dense gas releases in urban areas.  The PI has a good track record of recruiting graduate students from underrepresented groups and will work through university programs to recruit minority students for the research team. The research team will work with the PI on educational outreach through the development of physical demonstrations to be used at school outreach events and written up for use by teachers in STEM classes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Dense (heavy) gasses, such as chlorine, released in urban areas can become trapped at street level between buildings as the weight of the gas prevents it being mixed up into the atmosphere. The goal of this project is to quantify how much slower this mixing is compared to gas releases that are the same density as air. This was done using a series of small-scale experiments in which the atmospheric wind flow was modeled using water flowing in a channel and the dense gas release was modeled using salt water. We measured the density of the fluid in the wake of a model building over time. This was done using a laser, a fluorescent dye, and a high resolution black and white camera. The salt water was released upstream of a model building, flowed around the building and became trapped in the building wake. After an initial spike in concentration the dense fluid is slowly flushed out of the wake. Our observations showed that the fluid trapped in the building wake is slowly moved upstream toward the leeward side of the building where it is then lifted to the top of the building and flushed downstream. This process is very intermittent. Observations and our measurements show small parcels of dense fluid breaking off from the bulk of the salt water and travelling upstream toward the building. Concentration measurements show large spikes occurring throughout the flushing process as shown in Figure 1. For the flow in the diagram the vertical axis is the density of the fluid divided by the density of the fluid when it was released. The horizontal axis is a measure of time.

Experiments were run for a wide range of volumes of salt water and salt-water densities. We measured the time taken for the salt water to be flushed from the wake. Our results show that the retention time for the densest salt solution tested was six times that of the least dense solution. A second set of experiments were run in which there was a continuous release of dense salt solution. In this case the concentration of dense fluid in the building oscillated around a steady average. The denser the fluid release the higher the mean concentration. Again, there were large fluctuations about this mean. See Figure 2.

These experimental results are the first of their kind to quantify the trapping of dense gasses in a building wake over a large range of pollutant densities and wind speeds. These results are invaluable as a resource for validating computational models and have improved our understanding of the risk of such releases to the occupants of urban areas.

The research work has had a broader impact beyond the scientific discoveries. As part of this research project the research team has also worked to raise awareness of the risk associated with air pollution. The team has participated in several outreach programs to connect with high school students to encourage them to study engineering. Most recently we worked with high school students from the Carolinas and Georgia to look at indoor air pollution. We used a set of low-cost air quality sensors to highlight the various pollutants that occur indoors and discussed simple methods for improving indoor air quality. We have also developed demonstrations to aid in the teaching of engineering fluid mechanics that illustrate the interesting ways density can influence air and water flows. These demonstrations have been published online for other teachers to use in their classrooms (https://teachingfluids.wordpress.com/).


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Nigel Kaye
